items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels continue to remain high throughout the Bristol Avon Upper catchment following yesterdays small rainfall showers. 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near watercourses.

Up to 5-to10 mm is forecast today, Sunday the 1st December, we are not expecting flood warnings to be issued from Sundays rainfall. We continue to monitor the river levels and respond to the issues caused by Storm Bert last weekend. The weather outlook for Monday to Tuesday is currently forecasting very small rainfall totals, which should help to reduce river levels.

This message will be updated by 10:30 AM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Churn following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today in the Cerney Wick area. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
No further property flooding is currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Windrush, therefore flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. Water levels are expected to continue falling slowly but will remain high in many places over the next few days.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels have fallen on the River Evenlode but remain high the River Glyme. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue along the River Glyme at Woodstock. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels on the River Glyme are expected to remain high over the next few days and will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens and we are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is possible. A flood warning is in force for the River Thames at Abingdon. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Thames. Flooding of property, low lying land and roads remains possible today, in the areas around Abingdon and Culham. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. We expect river levels to continue dropping over the coming days but will remain high.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the Ginge Brook. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to remain high and sensitive to heavy showers.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Nene
items.message: River levels remain high following recent heavy rainfall in the River Nene catchment. The Lower River Nene is now rising, and will remain high over the next few days, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely, and therefore flood warnings are expected to be issued from tomorrow. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Monday 2nd December, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain has fallen in the last week causing River levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide, the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Monday 2nd December, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is possible. 

River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Ray at Islip. Flooding of property and roads remains possible, however further property flooding is not expected. Areas most at risk are properties located closest to the river on Mill Street. 

The weather forecast is for light showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue to slowly fall over the coming days. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.  

Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated this evening, 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is possible. Flood warnings are currently in force for the River Ray from the Heath Bridge area to and including the Otmoor Basin and the River Ray for Islip.
 
River levels are high but falling on the River Ray. Flooding of properties remains possible with flooding of low lying land and roads expected to continue. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue falling over the coming days but will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River levels remain high in the River Nene following recent heavy rainfall, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely and therefore flood warnings have been issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Monday 2nd December, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
No further property flooding is expected, and our flood warnings are no longer in force for the River Thame at Dorchester.

River levels are high but falling on the lower reaches of the River Thame. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue falling over the next few days, but they will remain high. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
The level in the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake has risen above the flood alert threshold but is stable. The River Cam, River Wriggle and the Stoford and Berwick Streams have risen following overnight rainfall but are now stable or falling. There is a risk of minor flooding of low-lying land and roads during Sunday. Road flooding may affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. 
Some light showers may occur during Sunday and Monday. We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely, and are checking rivers for blockages. Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying roads and footpaths close to rivers. 
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Avon and its tributaries. Rising ground water will keep river levels high. Flooding is possible.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
A further 8-15mm of rain fell this morning, Sunday 01/12/2024. This is not expected to cause more flooding but will keep levels higher for longer.
We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 15:00 PM on 2/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to recent rainfall. The forecast is for some showers over the next few days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. This information is correct as of 07:30am on Monday 2 December 2024. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 68 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Earith has approximately 15 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 60 centimetres of water on the road. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road at Earith, and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. We will update this message by 4pm today, Monday 2 December 2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower Colne.

Flooding to low lying land and roads may continue to affect locations near the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, Poyle Channel, Staines Moor and Longford.

Some light rain showers may occur over the next few days, but no further flooding is expected. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 6pm on Monday 2nd December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
Tern and Perry (031WAF104)   

River levels remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible over the next few days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours but showers are possible. We expect river levels to remain high for several days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.     

This message will be updated by 10:00am on Tuesday 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Dikler and flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible.

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Leach, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially around Lechlade. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. Water levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are slowly falling on the Chertsey Bourne following heavy rainfall last week. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 02/12/24, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. Some light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, but river levels are slowly falling and we expect this to continue over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene due to recent heavy rainfall. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Monday 2nd December, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray from the Heath Bridge area to and including the Otmoor Basin

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook

items.message:
Property flooding remains possible. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Ray. Flooding of property and roads remains possible, however further property flooding is not expected. 

The weather forecast is for light showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue to slowly fall over the coming days, but levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  

Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated this evening, 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester, may also be affected. The forecast is for some further rainfall today, Sunday 1 December, followed by showers over the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, Monday 2 December 2024.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
Flooding is possible as the Lower River Frome and its tributaries, remain high.  Increasing ground water is also keeping rivers high. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
A further 8-15mm of rain fell this morning, Sunday 01/12/2024. This will cause rivers to rise again.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 2/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches
items.message: Occasional showers are forecast for Monday, 02/12/2024, and a mainly dry day on Tuesday. We expect river levels to continue to fall. However, the early forecast is for further rain on Wednesday and Thursday and this flood alert may be reissued.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.       

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours but showers are possible. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.      

This message will be updated by 10:00am on Tuesday 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths will continue today, Monday 2nd December, and tomorrow. High water levels may last for a few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 3rd December.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.10m and is stable. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.91m and is stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. River levels have slightly risen following the overnight rainfall and pumping has currently stopped at Huish Episcopi and Long Load. We will recommence pumping as soon as river levels allow. 
Occasional light rain and showers are forecast for Sunday and Monday.  We continue to monitor the situation, clearing weed screens and checking rivers for blockages. Don't put yourself or others at risk. For further details, please search for Somerset emergency road closure. This message will be updated by 2 PM on 02/12/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the Bear Brook and flooding of low lying land and roads is possible in the Aylesbury area. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. Levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels continue to remain high throughout the Bristol Avon Upper and Mid catchments following yesterdays small rainfall showers. 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near watercourses.

Up to 5-to10 mm is forecast today, Sunday the 1st December, we are not expecting flood warnings to be issued from Sundays rainfall. We continue to monitor the river levels and respond to the issues caused by Storm Bert last weekend. The weather outlook for Monday to Tuesday is currently forecasting very small rainfall totals, which should help to reduce river levels.

This message will be updated by 10:30 AM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: East Somerset Rivers

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
River levels on the River Brue have started to rise in response to the overnight rainfall but will remain below levels of concern. However, the flood alert remains in force due to significant water on the Somerset Levels and Moors. The flooding of low lying roads and land continues during Sunday 01/12/2024. Flooding is possible near the River Brue and River Sheppey, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road. 
Occasional light rain and showers are forecast for Sunday and Monday. We continue to monitor the situation closely, and staff have been out checking rivers for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths close to rivers. 
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ock from Watchfield to Abingdon, and also the Letcombe Brook at Wantage, Grove and East Hanney
items.message:
No further property flooding is expected.  Flood Warnings have been removed for the River Ock at Abingdon.

River levels have fallen on the River Ock but remain high on the Letcombe Brook. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible along the Letcombe Brook near Wantage. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels on the Letcombe Brook are expected to remain high over the next few days and remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Mythe Bridge, Haw Bridge and Sandhurst River gauges because of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains a possibility. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore.      

Observed peaks:   

Mythe 4.68m on Tuesday, 26/11/2024,    

Haw Bridge 5.12m on Thursday 28/11/2024,     

Sandhurst 3.92m and Gloucester 3.38m on Friday morning 29/11/2024. 

Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may cause a small rise in river levels.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.     

This message will be updated by 11am, Tuesday 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
River levels remain below the threshold for this flood alert. However, the drain level on the moor at Westover Pumping Station remains high, but is currently falling. We will continue to pump water at Westover Pumping Station whilst river levels allow. The flooding of low lying land and roads remains a risk during Sunday, 01/12/2024. Areas most at risk include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road near the runway, the Mudford to Limington road and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate.
Occasional light rain and showers are forecast for Sunday and Monday.  We continue to monitor the situation closely, and staff have been out checking rivers for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths close to rivers. Don't put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leadon catchment
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains a possibility. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court.  

Further showers are forecast over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 11am, Tuesday 3/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.   

The risk of flooding from Storm Bert has now reduced.     

Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may cause a small rise in river levels.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.

items.description: River Axe area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Axe has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Further property flooding is not expected. A flood warning  in force for the River Thames from Northmoor Lock down to Eynsham. 

River levels are high but falling  along the River Thames. Flooding of property, low lying land and roads remains possible. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue dropping over the coming days but will remain high.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
No further property flooding is expected and our flood warnings are no longer in force for the River Thames and tributaries at New Botley, New and North Hinksey and Grandpont in Oxford. 

River levels are high but falling on the River Thames and its tributaries. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. 

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue dropping over the coming days but will remain high. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

items.message:
The river level on the Washford River in Beggearn Huish rose slightly following the overnight rainfall and is at the flood alert threshold. The flood alert remains in force and the flooding of low lying land and roads may continue during Sunday, 01/12/2024. There has been little response for other rivers in the area. Occasional light rain and showers are forecast for Sunday and Monday.
We continue to monitor the situation closely, and staff have been out checking rivers for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Dorset Rivers and Streams

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65mAOD at 14:45 on 02/12/24 and 4.85mAOD at 03:00 on 03/12/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 285 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Cae Howel river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Cae Howel; 3.4 - 3.6m this evening, Monday 02/12/24. 
We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday Morning, 03/12/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on Tuesday 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the River Thames as a result of high tides in combination with high flows from upstream following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 15:00 this afternoon (02/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 5m and 5.14m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The next high tide is expected at 03:00 tomorrow morning (03/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.1m and 5.24m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The following high tide is expected at 16:00 tomorrow afternoon (03/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 4.94m and 5.08m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible from this tide. 
We are monitoring the situation carefully and will issue an update if the situation changes. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

The next high tide is expected at Kingston at 15:15 this afternoon (02/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.07m and 5.21m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The next high tide is expected at 03:15 tomorrow morning (03/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.18m and 5.32m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The following high tide is expected at 16:15 tomorrow afternoon (03/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 5m and 5.15m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is not expected from this tide. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The flooding of low-lying land and roads near the River Tone and on Currymoor continues during Sunday 01/12/2024. New Road and Cutts Road remain closed. The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.22m and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.61m and is falling. We are pumping at Currymoor and will continue to do so whilst river levels allow. We are also pumping at Northmoor, Saltmoor and Stanmoor when required.
Occasional light rain and showers are forecast for Sunday and Monday.  We continue to monitor the situation, clearing weed screens and checking rivers for blockages. Don't put yourself or others at risk. For further details, please search for Somerset emergency road closure. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:

Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may cause a small rise in river levels. 
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days with upto 20mm expected to fall over the next few days, which could see levels continue to rise.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high. Increasing ground water is keeping levels high.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible from 12:00 noon on 27/11/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
A further 8-15mm of rainfall has fallen this morning, Sunday 01/12/2024. This is not forecast to cause more flooding but will keep the levels high for longer.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 2/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected in the Twyford area. However, a Flood Warning is in force nearby on the River Thames at Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave.
River levels remain high but are continuing to decline on the River Loddon as water makes its way downstream following heavy rainfall last week. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 02/12/2024, especially in the Loddon Drive area of Wargrave, with flooding of roads affecting access to properties. Some light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, but we expect river levels to continue declining over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/12/24, or as the situation changes.

The weather forecast is for scattered showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at Britford, Salisbury
items.message:
River levels are continuing to slowly fall but rising groundwater will keep levels high.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Lower Road and Church Lane.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
A further 8-15mm of rainfall fell today, Sunday 01/12/2024. This is not expected to cause further flooding but levels will remain high as a result.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 2/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message:
River levels are continuing to slowly fall but rising ground water will keep levels high.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around south of the A36 at Salisbury to Blashford in Ringwood including Charlton All Saints, Breamore, Fordingbridge and Bickton. 
A further 8-15mm of rainfall fell this morning, Sunday 01/12/2024.This rainfall is not forecast to lead to any further flooding.
We will continue to monitor the situation.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 PM on 2/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message: Property flooding is expected. The Flood Warning for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave is currently in force. River levels remain high on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall due to Storm Bert and Storm Conall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads, and property is expected to continue today, 2/12/2024.  Today, 2/12/2024 and tomorrow, are expected to be mainly dry with some scattered showers. River levels are starting to fall and are expected to continue to fall over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation carefully and will issue an update if the situation changes. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is possible. 

River levels are high but falling on the River Thames at Abingdon. Flooding of property, low lying land and roads remains possible, especially properties closest to the Thames on Waters Edge, Bridge Street and East St. Helens Street. 

The weather forecast is for light showers over the coming days. We do not expect these showers to significantly affect river levels. River levels are expected to continue falling but will remain high.

Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services and operating weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated this evening, 02/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

The high tide after this is expected at 03:30 tomorrow morning (03/12/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.67m and 5.81m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole has risen to 111.09m, and may rise further due to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to plateau and fall over the next few days.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

items.message:
The threat of flooding from the Colne Brook has reduced and this flood alert has now been removed. 

Some light rain showers are forecast over the next few days but no further flooding is expected.

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Areas near the River Nene in Peterborough and surrounding villages
items.message: The River Nene has been falling steadily today Sunday 1st December and we do not expect any further flooding to properties at Peterborough and surrounding villages. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, and Medmenham

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham

items.description: River Loddon at Twyford, Charvil and Wargrave
